instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board missing Wifi and Bluetooth
threads.message:
This board came in without liquid damage, but with a missing screen backlight and non-sensitive Touch Bar. I found two burnt & melted inductors (L5100 and L8504) and a burnt via near <CHIP>U8500</CHIP>. Fixing those issues restored the backlight and Touch Bar.

But the board is missing Wifi and Bluetooth (no hardware recognized). It also does not read external USB drives. It does have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_WLANBT</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S_WLANBT</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board missing Wifi and Bluetooth
threads.message:
Something more affected by liquid.

Do you get 5V at USB devices connected?

You should check all resistors from page 32.
Maybe corroded trace too.
Also try reballing <CHIP>U3701</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board missing Wifi and Bluetooth
threads.message:
Again, no liquid damage on this board.
Yes, I get USB power on external devices. USB drives are also recognized when I start up with the option key pressed.
Resistors around <CHIP>U3701</CHIP> look good.
Are you suggesting removing the underfilled <CHIP>U3701</CHIP> and reballing it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board missing Wifi and Bluetooth
threads.message:
"This board came in without liquid damage"
--------------
"Again, no liquid damage on this board."
???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board missing Wifi and Bluetooth
threads.message:
For USB, you may have problems with <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>; try changing it.

You may need to change <CHIP>U3701</CHIP> too; should replace the Wifi/TBT ROMS from same donor board.
Try reballing it first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board missing Wifi and Bluetooth
threads.message: What's your theory of what happened here? How can overcurrent events on <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S_DFR_FILT</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S_DFR_FILT</SIGNAL> cause damage to the Wifi and the USB-C Data chip? Mysterious. I think it's more likely that something else got damaged (CPU? T2?).
